column1: Index	Title	Content
0	Communication: Summary	"Communication is the act of conveying meanings from one entity or group to another through the use of mutually understood signs and semiotic rules.
The main steps inherent to all communication are:
The formation of communicative motivation or reason.
Message composition.
Message encoding.
Transmission of the encoded message as a sequence of signals using a specific channel or medium.
Noise sources such as natural forces and in some cases human activity begin influencing the quality of signals propagating from the sender to one or more receivers.
Reception of signals and reassembling of the encoded message from a sequence of received signals.
Decoding of the reassembled encoded message.
Interpretation and making sense of the presumed original message.The scientific study of communication can be divided into:
Information theory which studies the quantification
column2: storage
column3: and communication of information in general;

column1: Communication studies which concerns human communication;
Biosemiotics which examines communication in and between living organisms in general.The channel of communication can be visual
column2: auditory
column3: tactile and haptic
column5: electromagnetic

column1: Human communication is unique for its extensive use of abstract language. Development of civilization has been closely linked with progress in telecommunication."

column1: 2	Communication: Verbal	"Verbal communication is the spoken or written conveyance of a message. Language learning normally occurs most intensively during human childhood. Most of the thousands of human languages use patterns of sound or gesture for symbols which enable communication with others around them. Languages tend to share certain properties

column1: 6	Communication: Family	"Family communication is the study of the communication perspective in a broadly defined family
column2: with intimacy and trusting relationship. The main goal of family communication is to understand the interactions of family and the pattern of behaviors of family members in different circumstances. Open and honest communication creates an atmosphere that allows family members to express their differences as well as love and admiration for one another. It also helps to understand the feelings of one another.

column1: Family communication study looks at topics such as family rules
column2: family roles or family dialectics and how those factors could affect the communication between family members. Researchers develop theories to understand communication behaviors. Family communication study also digs deep into certain time periods of family life such as marriage
column3: parenthood or divorce and how communication stands in those situations. It is important for family members to understand communication as a trusted way which leads to a well constructed family."

This means that relational messages come across in how one says something and it demonstrates a person’s feelings

column1: 8	Communication: Barriers to effectiveness	"Barriers to effective communication can retard or distort the message or intention of the message being conveyed. This may result in failure of the communication process or cause an effect that is undesirable. These include filtering
column2: selective perception
column3: information overload
column5: language
column7: communication apprehension
column8: gender differences and political correctnessThis also includes a lack of expressing ""knowledge-appropriate"" communication
column9: which occurs when a person uses ambiguous or complex legal words
column11: or descriptions of a situation or environment that is not understood by the recipient.

column1: Physical barriers- Physical barriers are often due to the nature of the environment. An example of this is the natural barrier which exists if staff is located in different buildings or on different sites. Likewise
column2: poor or outdated equipment
column3: particularly the failure of management to introduce new technology
column4: may also cause problems. Staff shortages are another factor which frequently causes communication difficulties for an organization.

column1: System design- System design faults refer to problems with the structures or systems in place in an organization. Examples might include an organizational structure which is unclear and therefore makes it confusing to know whom to communicate with. Other examples could be inefficient or inappropriate information systems
column2: a lack of supervision or training
column3: and a lack of clarity in roles and responsibilities which can lead to staff being uncertain about what is expected of them.

column1: Attitudinal barriers- Attitudinal barriers come about as a result of problems with staff in an organization. These may be brought about
column2: for example
column3: by such factors as poor management
column5: personality conflicts which can result in people delaying or refusing to communicate
column6: the personal attitudes of individual employees which may be due to lack of motivation or dissatisfaction at work
column7: brought about by insufficient training to enable them to carry out particular tasks
column8: or simply resistance to change due to entrenched attitudes and ideas.

column1: Ambiguity of words/phrases- Words sounding the same but having different meaning can convey a different meaning altogether. Hence the communicator must ensure that the receiver receives the same meaning. It is better if such words are avoided by using alternatives whenever possible.
Individual linguistic ability- The use of jargon

column1: Physiological barriers- These may result from individuals' personal discomfort
column2: caused—for example—by ill health
column3: poor eyesight or hearing difficulties.

column1: Bypassing-These happens when the communicators do not attach the same symbolic meanings to their words. It is when the sender is expressing a thought or a word but the receiver takes it in a different meaning. For example- ASAP

2) Non verbal communication is a very wide concept and it includes all the other forms of communication which do not uses written or spoken words. Non verbal communication takes following forms:

column1: Proxemics deals with the concept of space element in communication. Proxemics explains four zones of spaces namely intimate personal

column1: Artifactics studies about the non verbal signals or communication which emerges from personal accessories such as dresses or fashion accessories worn and it varies with culture as people of different countries follow different dressing codes.

column2: silences and response lag during an interaction. This aspect of communication is also influenced by cultural differences as it is well known that there is a great difference in the value given by different cultures to time.

column1: 13	Communication: Plants and fungi	"Communication is observed within the plant organism

column6: they do not trigger the fungal organism to react. This implies that fungal organisms can differentiate between molecules taking part in biotic messages and similar molecules being irrelevant in the situation. So far five different primary signalling molecules are known to coordinate different behavioral patterns such as filamentation
column7: mating
column8: growth
column9: and pathogenicity. Behavioral coordination and production of signaling substances is achieved through interpretation processes that enables the organism to differ between self or non-self
column15: i.e. similar molecules without biotic content."

column1: 14	Communication: Bacteria quorum sensing	"Communication is not a tool used only by humans

column1: This was first observed by Fuqua et al. in marine microorganisms like V. harveyi and V. fischeri."

15	Communication: Models	"The first major model for communication was introduced by Claude Shannon and Warren Weaver for Bell Laboratories in 1949 The original model was designed to mirror the functioning of radio and telephone technologies. Their initial model consisted of three primary parts: sender
column2: channel
column3: and receiver. The sender was the part of a telephone a person spoke into
column4: the channel was the telephone itself
column5: and the receiver was the part of the phone where one could hear the other person. Shannon and Weaver also recognized that often there is static that interferes with one listening to a telephone conversation

column1: In a simple model
column2: often referred to as the transmission model or standard view of communication
column3: information or content is sent in some form from an emisor/ sender/ encoder to a destination/ receiver/ decoder. This common conception of communication simply views communication as a means of sending and receiving information. The strengths of this model are simplicity
column5: and quantifiability. Claude Shannon and Warren Weaver structured this model based on the following elements:

column1: An information source
column2: which produces a message.

column1: A transmitter
column2: which encodes the message into signals

column1: A channel
column2: to which signals are adapted for transmission

column1: A noise source
column2: which distorts the signal while it propagates through the channel

column1: A receiver
column2: which 'decodes' the message from the signal.

column1: A destination
column2: where the message arrives.Shannon and Weaver argued that there were three levels of problems for communication within this theory.

column1: The technical problem: how accurately can the message be transmitted?
The semantic problem: how precisely is the meaning 'conveyed'?
The effectiveness problem: how effectively does the received meaning affect behavior?Daniel Chandler critiques the transmission model by stating:
It assumes communicators are isolated individuals.
No allowance for differing purposes.
No allowance for differing interpretations.
No allowance for unequal power relations.
No allowance for situational contexts.In 1960
column2: David Berlo expanded on Shannon and Weaver's linear model of communication and created the SMCR Model of Communication. The Sender-Message-Channel-Receiver Model of communication separated the model into clear parts and has been expanded upon by other scholars.

column1: Theories of coregulation describe communication as a creative and dynamic continuous process
column2: rather than a discrete exchange of information. Canadian media scholar Harold Innis had the theory that people use different types of media to communicate and which one they choose to use will offer different possibilities for the shape and durability of society. His famous example of this is using ancient Egypt and looking at the ways they built themselves out of media with very different properties stone and papyrus. Papyrus is what he called 'Space Binding'. it made possible the transmission of written orders across space
column3: empires and enables the waging of distant military campaigns and colonial administration. The other is stone and 'Time Binding'
column4: through the construction of temples and the pyramids can sustain their authority generation to generation
column5: through this media they can change and shape communication in their society."

column1: 16	Communication: Noise	"In any communication model
column2: noise is interference with the decoding of messages sent over a channel by an encoder. There are many examples of noise:

column1: Environmental noise. Noise that physically disrupts communication
column2: such as standing next to loud speakers at a party
column3: or the noise from a construction site next to a classroom making it difficult to hear the professor.

column1: Physiological-impairment noise. Physical maladies that prevent effective communication
column2: such as actual deafness or blindness preventing messages from being received as they were intended.

column1: Semantic noise. Different interpretations of the meanings of certain words. For example
column2: the word ""weed"" can be interpreted as an undesirable plant in a yard
column3: or as a euphemism for marijuana.

column1: Syntactical noise. Mistakes in grammar can disrupt communication
column2: such as abrupt changes in verb tense during a sentence.

column1: Organizational noise. Poorly structured communication can prevent the receiver from accurate interpretation. For example
column2: unclear and badly stated directions can make the receiver even more lost.

column1: Cultural noise. Stereotypical assumptions can cause misunderstandings
column2: such as unintentionally offending a non-Christian person by wishing them a ""Merry Christmas"".

column1: Psychological noise. Certain attitudes can also make communication difficult. For instance
column2: great anger or sadness may cause someone to lose focus on the present moment. Disorders such as autism may also severely hamper effective communication.To face communication noise
column3: redundancy and acknowledgement must often be used. Acknowledgements are messages from the addressee informing the originator that his/her communication has been received and is understood. Message repetition and feedback about message received are necessary in the presence of noise to reduce the probability of misunderstanding.

column1: The act of disambiguation regards the attempt of reducing noise and wrong interpretations
column2: when the semantic value or meaning of a sign can be subject to noise
column3: or in presence of multiple meanings
column4: which makes the sense-making difficult. Disambiguation attempts to decrease the likelihood of misunderstanding. This is also a fundamental skill in communication processes activated by counselors
column5: psychotherapists
column7: and in coaching sessions based on colloquium. In Information Technology
column8: the disambiguation process and the automatic disambiguation of meanings of words and sentences has also been an interest and concern since the earliest days of computer treatment of language."
